{
  "concepts": [
    {"term": "Radon transform", "category": "mathematics"},
    {"term": "sinogram", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "X-ray projection data", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "amplitude", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "reconstructed CT image", "category": "reconstruction"},
    {"term": "theta", "category": "mathematics"},
    {"term": "function f of x and y", "category": "mathematics"}
  ],
  "evidence": [
    "The Radon transform is essentially a way to represent X-ray projection data",
    "the result is something called a sinogram",
    "objects that are closer to the center of the field of view show up as regions of higher amplitude in the sinogram",
    "the sinogram is the bridge between the raw projection data we collect and the reconstructed CT image we want to build",
    "it describes how the function f of x and y, our object, is projected along different angles, which we denote by theta"
  ]
}

concepts.term: function f of x and y

evidence: The Radon transform is essentially a way to represent X-ray projection data
the result is something called a sinogram
objects that are closer to the center of the field of view show up as regions of higher amplitude in the sinogram
the sinogram is the bridge between the raw projection data we collect and the reconstructed CT image we want to build
it describes how the function f of x and y, our object, is projected along different angles, which we denote by theta
